captions.text:
Hi there my name’s John Green, this is Crash
Course: World History and today we’re gonna

talk about Alexander the Great, but to do
that we’re going to begin by talking about

ideals of masculinity and heroism and Kim
Kardashian and the Situation.
Mr Green, Mr Green, Mr. Green! Which Situation?

Oh, me from the past, I forgot you wanted
to go to Columbia. Me from the present regrets
to inform you that you do not get in.

But since you live in the past, you have no
way of knowing who I’m talking about, and

it occurs to me that this video may be watched
in some glorious future when Kim Kardashian

and the Situation have mercifully disappeared
from public life, and the supermarket tabloids,

instead of talking about celebrities talk
about Foucault and the Higgs-Boson particle,

so Kim Kardashian is a professional famous
person who rose to notoriety by scoodilypoopin

with someone named Ray Jay, and Mike “The
Situation” I forgot his last name is a professional
stupid person with big muscles.

They’re both known by millions, lives in
luxury, and people literally pay to own their
odors.

Why do these people crave fame? Why do any
of us? Well, I’d argue it’s not about

money. If it were our tabloids would be devoted
to the lives and times of bankers.

I think we all want to leave a legacy. We
want to be remembered. We want to be Great.
[music intro]
[music intro]
[music intro]
[music intro]
[music intro]
[music intro]

For a long time, history was all about the
Study of Great Men, and it was common to call

people as “the Great,” but these days
historians are less likely to do that, because

they recognize that one man’s Great is generally
another man’s Terrible.

And also “the Great” has some misogynistic
implications, like, it’s almost always associated

with men. You never hear about Cleopatra the
Great or Elizabeth the Great. There was, of

course, Catherine the Great of Russia, but
for her masculine Greatness she was saddled

with the completely untrue rumor that she
died trying to scoodilypoop with a horse.

Saddled? Get it? Anybody? Saddled with the
rumor?

Anyway, they could’ve soiled Catherine the
Great’s name just by telling the truth:

which is that like so many other Great men
and women, she died on the toilet. Get it?
soiled? Toilet? Yes? Yes!

So, quick biography of Alexander of Macedon,
born in 356 BCE, died in 323 BCE at the ripe
old age of 32.

Alexander was the son of King Philip the 2nd,
and when just 13 years old he tamed a horse

no one else could ride named Bucephalus, which
impressed his father so much he said:

“Oh thy son, look thee at a kingdom equal
to and worthy of thyself, for Macedonia is
too little for thee.”

By that time he was already an accomplished
general, but over the next decade he expanded

his empire with unprecedented speed and he
is famous for having never lost a battle.

Today we’re going to look at Alexander of
Macedon’s story by examining three possible
definitions of greatness.

First, maybe Alexander was great because of
his accomplishments.

This is an extension of the idea that history
is the record of the deeds of great men. Now,

of course, that’s ridiculous. For one thing,
half of people are women for another, there

are lots of historic events that no one can
take responsibility for, like for instance
the Black Plague.

But still, Alexander was accomplished. I mean,
he
conquered a lot of territory. Like, a lot.
No, not a lot, A LOT. Yes.

His father, Philip, had conquered all of Greece,
but Alexander did what the Spartans and Athenians

had failed to do: He destroyed the Persian
Empire. He conquered all the land the Persians

had held including Egypt, and then marched
toward India, stopping at the Indus River

only because his army was like, “Hey, Alexander,
you know what would be awesome? Not marching.”

Also, Alexander was a really good general,
although historians disagree over whether

his tactics were truly brilliant or if his
army just happened to have better technology,

specifically these extra long spears called
sarissas.

Much of his reputation as a general, and his
reputation in general, anybody? Puns? I should
stop? OK. Is because of Napoleon.

Napoleon like many other generals throughout
history, was obsessed with Alexander the Great,
but more on that in a moment.

That said, Alexander wasn’t very good at
what we might now call empire-building.

Alexander’s empire was definitely visually
impressive, but it wasn’t actually much

of an empire. Like, Alexander specialized
in the tearing down of things, but he wasn’t

so great at the building up of institutions
to replace the things he’d torn down.

And that’s why, pretty soon after his death,
the Greek Empire broke into three empires,
called the Hellenistic Kingdoms.

Each was ruled by one of Alexander’s generals,
and they became important dynasties. The Antigones

in Greece and Macedonia, the Ptolemies in
Egypt, the Selucids in Persia, all of which
lasted longer than Alexander’s empire.

A Second Greatness: Maybe Alexander was great
because he had an enormous impact on the world

after his death. Like King Tut, Alexander
the great was amazingly good at being a dead
person. Let’s go to the Thought Bubble.

So, After Alexander of Macedon died, everyone
from the Romans to Napoleon to Oliver Stone

loved him, and he was an important military
model for many generals throughout history.

But his main post-death legacy may be that
he introduced the Persian idea of Absolute

Monarchy to the Greco-Roman world, which would
become a pretty big deal.

Alexander also built a number of cities on
his route that became big deals after his

death, and it’s easy to spot them because
he named most of them after himself and one
after his horse.

The Alexandria in Egypt became a major center
of learning in the classical world, and was

home to the most amazing library ever, which
Julius Caesar probably “accidentally”

burned down while trying to conquer a bunch
of land to emulate his hero, Alexander the
Great.

Plus, the dead Alexander had a huge impact
on culture. He gave the region its common

language, Greek, which facilitated conversations
and commerce.

Greek was so widespread that archaeologists
have found coins in what is now Afghanistan

with pictures of their kings and the word
“king” written beneath the pictures—in

Greek. This is also why, incidentally, the
New Testament was eventually written in Greek.

Although Alexander was mostly just conquering
territory for the glory and heroism and greatness

of it all, in his wake emerged a more closely
connected world that could trade and communicate

with more people more efficiently than ever
before.

Alexander didn’t make those things happen,
but they probably wouldn’t have happened
without him. But here’s a question:

If you’re watching Keeping Up With the Kardashians
and get so involved in Kim’s marital travails

that you leave the bathwater running, thereby
flooding your house and necessitating a call

to a plumber, and then you fall in love with
the plumber and get married and live happily

ever after, does that make Kim Kardashian
responsible for your marriage?

Thanks, Thought Bubble. Okay, a third definition
of greatness: Maybe Alexander is great because
of his legend:

Since no accounts of his life were written
while he lived, embellishment was easy, and
maybe that’s where true greatness lies.

I mean the guy died at 32, before he ever
had a chance to get old and lose battles,

He was tutored by Aristotle, for God’s sakes.
Then there’s Alexander’s single-minded

Ahab-esque pursuit of the Persian king Darius,
who he chased across modern-day Iraq and Iran

for no real reason except he desperately wanted
to kill him, and when Bessus, one of Darius’s

generals, assassinated him before Alexander
had the chance, Alexander chased Bessus around
until he could at least kill him.

These almost-comical pursuits of glory and
heroism are accompanied in classical histories

by stories of Alexander walking through the
desert, and then suddenly raining, and these

ravens coming to lead him to the army he’s
supposed to fight, and stories of his hot

Persian wife Roxanna, who supposedly while
still a teenager engineered the assassinations
of many of Alexander’s fellow wives.

And even at his death, people tried to make
Alexander live up to this heroic ideal. Like,

Plutarch tells us that he died of a fever,
but that’s no way for a masculine, empire

building awesome person to die! So rumors
persist that he died either of alcohol poisoning
or else of assassination-y poisoning.
I mean, no great man can die of a fever.

Speaking of Great Men, it’s time to strip
down for the Open Letter.
So elegant.

But first let’s see what’s in the Secret
Compartment today. Oh. It’s Kim Kardashian’s

perfume. Thanks Stan. I’ll wear this. I’ll
check it out, I’ll give it a try.
[sprays self with super nasty crap]

C’ah. Wow. That is... mmm...it’s like
all the worst parts of baby powder and all
the worst parts of cat pee.
An Open Letter to the Ladies:
Hello, Ladies,

You’ve really been unfairly neglected in
Crash Course World History and also in World

History text books everywhere. Like, there
will be a whole chapter exploring the exploits

of great men and then at the end there will
be one sentence that’s like “also women

were doing stuff at the time and it was important,
but we don’t really know what it was, so
back to Alexander the Great...”

HIStory has been very good at marginalizing
and demeaning women and we’re going to fight

against that as we move forward in the story
of human civilization.

Ladies, I have to go now because my eyes are
stinging from the biological weapon known

as Kim Kardashian’s Gold. Seriously, don’t
wear it.

Best wishes,
John Green

So in Alexander the Great we have a story
about a man who united the world while riding

a magical horse only he could tame across
deserts where it magically rained for him

so that he could chase down his mortal enemy
and then leave in his wake a more enlightened
world and a gorgeous, murderous wife.

But of course it’s not just Assassin’s
Creed and Call of Duty that celebrate the

idea that ennobled violence can lead to a
better world.

And that takes us to my opinion of how Alexander
really came to be Great. Millennia after his

death in 1798, Napoleon invaded Egypt, not
because he particularly needed to invade Egypt

but because he wanted to do what Alexander
had done.

And long before Napoleon, the Romans really
worshipped Alexander particularly the Roman

General Pompey, AKA Pompeius Magnus, AKA Pompey
the Great.

Pompey was so obsessed with Alexander that
he literally tried to emulate Alexander’s
boyishly disheveled hair style.

In short, Alexander was Great because others
decided he was Great. Because they chose to
admire and emulate him.

Yes, Alexander was a great general. Yes, he
conquered a lot of land. The Situation is

also really good at picking up girls...of
a certain type.

And Kim Kardashian is good at- Stan, what
is Kim Kardashian good at? Oh. Ah. I guess
just a body type then. Something...

We made Alexander Great, just as today we
make people great when we admire them and
try to emulate them.

History has traditionally been in the business
of finding and celebrating great men, and

only occasionally great women, but this obsession
with Greatness is troubling to me.

It wrongly implies, first, history is made
primarily by men and secondly, that history

is made primarily by celebrated people, which
of course makes us all want to be celebrities.

Thankfully we’ve left behind the idea that
the best way to become an icon is to butcher

people and conquer a lot of land, but the
ideals that we’ve embraced instead aren’t
necessarily worth celebrating either.

All of which is to say we decide what to worship
and what to care about and what to pay attention

to. We decide whether to care about The Situation.
Alexander couldn’t make history in a vacuum,

and neither can anyone else. Thanks for watching
and I’ll see you next week.

Crash Course is produced and Directed by Stan
Muller, the show is written by my high school

history teacher Raoul Meyer and myself. Our
script supervisor is Danica Johnson and our
graphics team is Thought Bubble.

Last week’s phrase of the week was "Thinly
Sliced Trees". If you want to take a guess

at this week’s phrase or suggest new ones
you can do so in comments. If you have questions

about today’s video you can also ask those
in comments and our team of historians will
attempt to answer them.

Thanks for watching Crash Course and as they
say in my hometown, don’t forget to be awesome.

the Great, his empire, his horse Bucephalus, the empires that came after 
him, and the idea of Greatness. Is greatness a question of accomplishment, 
of impact, or are people great because the rest of us decide they're great?

history, Catherine the Great's death (not via horse love), the ardent love 
other generals--from Pompey the Great to Napoleon--had for Alexander, a bit

comments.text:
This video has actually offended my sensibilities enough that I want to 
reply.

For the sake of completeness, I will address each remark in turn, and add 
further commentary where I feel it is helpful.

The text is reproduced below; there is also a Pastebin link here (older 
version):

http://pastebin.com/3jwghnTV

In the first place, as regards the concept of ‘great’ or ‘greatness’, we 
should keep Nietzsche in mind, who of course said: “Terribleness is part of 
greatness: let us not deceive ourselves.” It is completely possible for a 
king or tyrant to be terrible and yet not great, but the reverse does not 
hold: greatness presupposes terribleness, a willingness to inflict harm and 
pain and even death upon others for the purpose of achieving one’s goals in 
life; and still more, it presupposes a willingness to suffer these things 
oneself.

Alexander was by any appraisal a relatively mild and humane king. The 
murder of Kleitos is often cited as proof of his corruption and insanity, 
but by ancient and modern standards, there were relatively few massacres 
perpetrated by Alexander’s troops on their long campaign (Alexander 
instantly and deeply regretted killing Kleitos in a drunken brawl). Cities 
and armies that surrendered were granted pardon; those that fought and 
betrayed Alexander’s trust perished.

In all his years of conquest, Alexander never took any person as booty or 
as a ‘war prize’. The eunuch of Darius, Bagoas, was a gift to him from a 
Persian governor, and Alexander retained him out of mutual affection.

The whole argument about ‘greatness’ being inherently misogynistic or 
male-centric is nonsense. Very few people in history have ever held that 
title or had their name passed down to posterity with the title intact – 
this goes for men as well as women. The fact of the matter is that there 
have been extremely few female conquerors and high ranking monarchs 
throughout history, and the reasons for this could not be more obvious. 
Warfare was and remains the business of men; those who would make 
themselves masters of the battlefield must be willing and able to fight 
alongside their soldiers, or at any rate to lead them in combat.

The taming of Oxhead is a true story; the remark by Phillip to Alexander 
afterwards is apocryphal. Phillip fully intended to be the first Greek King 
to conquer lands in Asia; while Phillip lived, Alexander could hope for no 
better than to be a major general in his Macedonian army.

The three definitions of greatness are worth considering, but unfortunately 
they are not properly addressed here. The lens of modernity is far too 
clouded to allow accurate appraisal of Alexander’s legacy, firstly because 
of the remoteness of the subject and his life, and secondly because the 
contemporary attitude towards monarchs, wars of conquest, grandeur and so 
on is decidedly negative. In our time where kings and kingcraft are bound 
to seem a trifle preposterous (if not downright immoral) it is difficult 
for anyone to understand the mentality of those who lived during and after 
the time of Alexander. Like every other great conqueror in history, whether 
Ramses or Xerxes or Caesar or Napoleon, Alexander today would surely be put 
on trial for various war crimes, genocide and the like. It is therefore 
impossible, starting from this perspective, to appraise him honestly.

No serious military historian would contend that Alexander was anything 
less than a brilliant commander. His invention and use of superior 
implements was just another part of this brilliance. His real genius was in 
organizing and deploying various squadrons in battle, and rearranging these 
on the fly. He could move an entire division of archers or horsemen from 
one side of a vast plain to the other in a flash. More than anything, his 
lightning speed and tactical thinking was what enabled him to win in the 
face of wildly lopsided odds.

The comments about Alexander’s empire building ability are also 
misinformed. Alexander was very intelligent when it came to matters of 
statecraft. Wherever possible, he tried to leave the existing structure of 
civilization and government intact, changing perhaps a few key officials in 
order to maintain control over the conquered areas. Wherever he destroyed, 
he also created: the many cities that bore his name, several of which still 
exist today, are a testament to that. Moreover, it is something of an 
exaggeration to say that Alexander simply crushed the Persian Empire and 
moved on. Persian control of the lands within its borders was by no means 
absolute; all throughout the empire, there were provinces and peoples who 
fought amongst one another, refused to pay taxes, raided and looted 
agricultural settlements, and so on. In short, there was at least as much 
chaos before Alexander arrived as there was after he left. The difference 
was that, as a roving monarch, Alexander could and often enough would mount 
a force to bring dissenting tribes and cities to heel before his imperial 
power. His empire came apart at the seams not because it was poorly 
constructed, but because it absolutely had to have a monarch on the order 
of Alexander to preside over it. There was no one else who could combine 
the traits necessary of a Great King and essential to a general as 
Alexander did. No one else could control the Macedonian army or keep the 
various governors and lesser kings in line. Cyrus lived an additional 30 
years after his conquests were finished, but it still only took Alexander a 
lustrum to topple his empire.

As regards Alexander’s presence and power in death, there is a great 
article by Lauren O’Conner under the title of ‘Constructing the Past. The 
Remains of Alexander the Great: The God, The King, The Symbol.’ I highly 
recommend anyone who is interested in Alexander’s posthumous travels and 
influence to consult it.

Alexander’s policy of Perso-Grecian fusion receives surprisingly little 
attention in our time, considering the present obsession with ‘diversity’ 
and multiculturalism. Unlike most all conquering autocrats, Alexander 
attempted to preserve rather than purge the existing culture of the peoples 
he conquered. He was very much enamored with the Persian title of Great 
King or ‘Shahanshah’, and with Persian customs in general. As he spent more 
time among the Persians, he began to look critically on the coarseness of 
his fellow Macedonians.

The motivations that drove Alexander are a subject of much speculation and 
scholarly debate, and it betrays a want of perspective to simply attribute 
his drive to vainglory. Author Tony Buzan has said: "[Alexander's] goal in 
conquering the world was not simply to conquer the world, it wasn't [about] 
power; it was to acquire knowledge, and then to disseminate knowledge. He 
wanted to know everything, to have seen everything, and he wanted to have 
done everything". The influence of his tutor, Aristotle, is evident in this.

Another pathetically simplistic appraisal involves the assumption that all 
historical legends contain exaggeration. At any rate, this still cleaves 
both ways: not only are famous people celebrated in bombastic tones, they 
are also subject to bitter slander and defamation by those who despise them 
or their accomplishments. Both sides have influenced the legacy of 
Alexander that comes down to us. In addition to this, Alexander has an 
entire series of mythological travels and battles to his credit, called the 
‘Alexander Romance’. But more serious historians such as Arrian worked very 
hard to separate fact from fiction, examining source material which 
unfortunately is no longer available today.

Alexander’s pursuit of Darius is misrepresented here. After the disaster at 
Gaugamela, Darius III was deposed by a coalition of lesser nobles and 
chiefs, Bessos foremost among them. From this point forward, Darius had no 
actual power; he was a prisoner conveyed hither and thither by Bessos as 
the latter retreated to keep away from Alexander. Alexander pursued Darius 
because, even after he had been deposed, Alexander still saw him as the 
true King of Persia, and wanted to legitimize his succession to that 
throne. In this respect he was certainly influenced by Darius’ own mother, 
Sisygambis. We will have something to say about her later.

Alexander’s subsequent pursuit of Bessos is easy to understand. As he had 
by then become King of Persia, Alexander wanted to punish Bessos for his 
crimes against Darius, namely treason and regicide. There is nothing 
comical about it, either. Bessos commanded a significant force even after 
Darius was assassinated, and did his best to stir up local leaders to 
revolt against Alexander. He was thus not merely a large thorn in 
Alexander’s side, but also a significant liability.

It is quite interesting how at no point in this video does the narrator 
mention or attempt to debate Alexander’s sexuality. Indeed, based on the 
account given in this video alone, it would be quite easy to assume that 
Alexander was another heterosexual (white) male megalomaniac who took 
liberties with the women he had power over. Nothing could be further from 
the truth. Alexander’s lifelong partner and the one who meant the most to 
him was a boyhood friend called Hephaestion. The two were deeply intimate 
and almost certainly lovers. However, we must take care not to impose 
categories of sexual orientation and disposition onto peoples who had no 
notion of these. The concept of heterosexuality and homosexuality had no 
parlance in the ancient world; the distinction in Greece and Rome was only 
between the active (penetrating) participant and the passive (penetrated).

Roxana, for clarity, was not Persian but Bactrian. Alexander’s Persian wife 
was called Stateira, and she was poisoned by Roxana shortly after 
Alexander’s death while several months pregnant. Stateira was the daughter 
of Darius III and the granddaughter of Sisygambis. Her sister, Drypetis, 
was married to Hephaestion, and murdered alongside Stateira.

Again with the matter of Alexander’s death, the narrator’s insolence 
distorts his presentation of the facts. Alexander’s death remains a topic 
of hot contention not because of enduring attempts to lionize him, but 
because there are sharply conflicting accounts. The debate rages whether 
Alexander died of fever, of poisoning, or of both. Crucial to this debate 
is the timetable of his decline and death, which is also not made clear by 
extant accounts. The date and rough time of Alexander’s death is certain, 
but the days leading up to this are not. Some say he was taken ill after 
downing a heavy chalice of wine; some say that he fell sick after wading 
through the marshes around Babylon and died several days later. Of 
particular interest is Kassandros, son of the Macedonian regent Antipatros, 
and longtime enemy of Alexander. When Antipatros was summoned to Babylon, 
he sent his son instead; the latter was then brought in contact with his 
brother, Iollas, Alexander’s royal cupbearer. Later, Kassandros would wage 
war against the successors of Alexander, have Alexander’s mother killed, 
and poison Alexander’s wife Roxana alongside her adolescent son, Alexander 
IV, heir to the throne of Macedon.

Again, the ‘masculine bias’ of history is a largely inane topic, and I 
think we can leave it aside while discussing Alexander. The most notable 
and noble female figure in Alexander’s orbit was undoubtedly Sisygambis, 
mother of the deposed Persian king Darius III. When Alexander captured her 
and her tent following the Battle of Issus, they spent a great deal of time 
conversing together about matters of statecraft and conquest. Sisygambis 
would later disown her real son in death and adopt Alexander; Alexander for 
his part held her in higher regard even than his own mother, Olympias. 
Speaking his mind later in life, he said of Sisygambis: “there is the Great 
King who would have led your people (the Persians) to prosperity and 
glory”. When Alexander died, Sisygambis promptly locked herself away and 
refused nutriment, expiring just a few days later.

The limited amount of scholarship that went into creating this video is 
betrayed further by the remarks on Alexander’s Roman legacy. Pompey might 
have imitated his hairstyle, but the most fervent devotee of Alexander was 
undoubtedly Emperor Caracalla, who believed himself to be Alexander 
reincarnated, going so far as to deploy his troops in outdated Macedonian 
gear and formations. He also had several philosophers of the Aristotelian 
school put to the sword on the belief that Aristotle had had a hand in 
poisoning Alexander.

As a very brief rebuttal to the conclusion of this video, I would only say 
that Alexander made himself great through his deeds, his passions, his 
dreams, and his style of kingship. The legend that surrounds him is in 
consequence of these; it did not develop out of nothing. Alexander was for 
many people of many persuasions a paragon, an ideal, and a hero who 
motivated them to strive for greatness in their own lives. He had 
tremendous energy and stamina, almost beyond belief; he was also deeply 
compassionate, arranging his forces in such a way as to always minimize 
casualties, and when casualties were had, he would wander the camp and 
personally attend on his wounded comrades. Shortly before his death, the 
veterans among his army recoiled at the idea of being separated from him 
even though many of them were past their sixth decade of life. 

Arrian, among the most prominent Alexander historians, closes his account 
of Alexander’s campaigns with the following admonition:

“Anyone who reproaches Alexander should not simply cite those deeds that 
deserve to be reproached. Instead, after collecting in one place all of 
Alexander’s qualities, let his critic then consider who he is and what sort 
of fortune he has had that he reproaches Alexander, a man who became so 
great and attained such a peak of human success as undisputed king of both 
continents whose name reached every land – whereas he is a lesser man, 
toiling at lesser things and not even handling them with any ability.”﻿
